ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The determination of the amount of respiratory syncytial virus in a sample.

Concepts.definition: The determination of the amount of respiratory syncytial virus in a sample.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Polymerase Chain Reaction Influenza B Virus

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Polymerase Chain Reaction Influenza B Virus
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method for amplifying a DNA base sequence using multiple rounds of heat denaturation of the DNA and annealing of oligonucleotide primers complementary to flanking regions in the presence of a heat-stable polymerase.  This results in duplication of the targeted DNA region. Newly synthesized DNA strands can subsequently serve as additional templates for the same primer sequences, so that successive rounds of primer annealing, strand elongation, and dissociation produce rapid and highly specific amplification of the desired sequence. PCR also can be used to detect the existence of the defined sequence in a DNA sample.: A negative-strand linear single-strand RNA virus with an 8 segment genome. Virions are enveloped and usually spherical or pleomorphic, 50-120 nm in diameter. Influenza B viruses are usually found only in humans. Unlike influenza A viruses, these viruses are not classified according to subtype.

Concepts.definition: A method for amplifying a DNA base sequence using multiple rounds of heat denaturation of the DNA and annealing of oligonucleotide primers complementary to flanking regions in the presence of a heat-stable polymerase.  This results in duplication of the targeted DNA region. Newly synthesized DNA strands can subsequently serve as additional templates for the same primer sequences, so that successive rounds of primer annealing, strand elongation, and dissociation produce rapid and highly specific amplification of the desired sequence. PCR also can be used to detect the existence of the defined sequence in a DNA sample.

A negative-strand linear single-strand RNA virus with an 8 segment genome. Virions are enveloped and usually spherical or pleomorphic, 50-120 nm in diameter. Influenza B viruses are usually found only in humans. Unlike influenza A viruses, these viruses are not classified according to subtype.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Polymerase Chain Reaction Influenza A Virus

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Polymerase Chain Reaction Influenza A Virus
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method for amplifying a DNA base sequence using multiple rounds of heat denaturation of the DNA and annealing of oligonucleotide primers complementary to flanking regions in the presence of a heat-stable polymerase.  This results in duplication of the targeted DNA region. Newly synthesized DNA strands can subsequently serve as additional templates for the same primer sequences, so that successive rounds of primer annealing, strand elongation, and dissociation produce rapid and highly specific amplification of the desired sequence. PCR also can be used to detect the existence of the defined sequence in a DNA sample.: A negative-strand linear single-strand RNA virus with an 8 segment genome. Virions are enveloped and usually spherical or pleomorphic, 80-120 nm in diameter. Subtyping is based on the antigenic properties of the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase proteins. Influenza type A viruses can infect people, birds, pigs, horses, and other animals, but wild birds are the natural hosts for these viruses.

Concepts.definition: A method for amplifying a DNA base sequence using multiple rounds of heat denaturation of the DNA and annealing of oligonucleotide primers complementary to flanking regions in the presence of a heat-stable polymerase.  This results in duplication of the targeted DNA region. Newly synthesized DNA strands can subsequently serve as additional templates for the same primer sequences, so that successive rounds of primer annealing, strand elongation, and dissociation produce rapid and highly specific amplification of the desired sequence. PCR also can be used to detect the existence of the defined sequence in a DNA sample.

A negative-strand linear single-strand RNA virus with an 8 segment genome. Virions are enveloped and usually spherical or pleomorphic, 80-120 nm in diameter. Subtyping is based on the antigenic properties of the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase proteins. Influenza type A viruses can infect people, birds, pigs, horses, and other animals, but wild birds are the natural hosts for these viruses.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Rapid Antigen Test Influenza B Antigen Measurement

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Rapid Antigen Test Influenza B Antigen Measurement
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An immunoassay that can quickly detect the presence of specific antigens in a sample and return results during a patient visit.: The determination of the amount of the Influenza B antigen in a sample.

Concepts.definition: An immunoassay that can quickly detect the presence of specific antigens in a sample and return results during a patient visit.
The determination of the amount of the Influenza B antigen in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.
ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2023.3.7 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0002119. ak

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A species of chlamydiae bacteria that infects humans and is a major cause of pneumonia.

Concepts.definition: A species of chlamydiae bacteria that infects humans and is a major cause of pneumonia.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A species of anaerobic, Gram-negative, pseudo-cocci shaped bacteria assigned to the phylum Firmicutes. This species is motile, grows best in SP-4 medium supplemented with glucose and is positive for beta-hemolysis. M. pneumoniae is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia, especially in people younger than 40.

Concepts.definition: A species of anaerobic, Gram-negative, pseudo-cocci shaped bacteria assigned to the phylum Firmicutes. This species is motile, grows best in SP-4 medium supplemented with glucose and is positive for beta-hemolysis. M. pneumoniae is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia, especially in people younger than 40.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The determination of the amount of coronaviridae in a sample.

Concepts.definition: The determination of the amount of coronaviridae in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The determination of the amount of human rhinovirus/enterovirus RNA present in a sample.

Concepts.longName: Human rhinovirus and/or enterovirus RNA Measurement
Concepts.definition: The determination of the amount of human rhinovirus/enterovirus RNA present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A group of DNA containing viruses which infect mammals and are capable of causing respiratory disease, including one form of the common cold.

Concepts.definition: A group of DNA containing viruses which infect mammals and are capable of causing respiratory disease, including one form of the common cold.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated definition to match current NCIt. 11.24.20 mc

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any of several paramyxoviruses (genus Respirovirus and Rubulavirus) that are a frequent cause of infections of the lower respiratory tract.

Concepts.definition: A non-taxanomic group of paramyxoviruses (genus Respirovirus and Rubulavirus) that are a frequent cause of infections of the lower respiratory tract.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A species of metapneumovirus in the family Paramyxoviridae. Infections with human metapneumovirus can cause upper and lower respiratory tract infections in patients of all ages but respiratory illnesses most often occur in young children or older adults.

Concepts.definition: A species of nonsegmented, negative-strand ssRNA viruses in the family Paramyxoviridae. Infections with human metapneumovirus can cause upper and lower respiratory tract infections in patients of all ages. This virus is second only to respiratory syncytial virus as the most commonly identified cause of pediatric lower respiratory illness.
